title: Want to sale the house, but have lien on that
question: We had filed bankruptcy on 2012, by that time we given up the business in order to keep our 2 houses. But now we want to sale one house to pay our debit . Can some lawyer help us
answers: Your questions, unfortunately, is not detailed sufficiently to understand the status of the house and liens. As discussed by my colleagues, if you are just talking about selling the house after bankruptcy, that has a mortgage on it, then you are able to just sell. The mortgage lien remained on the property after the bankruptcy. If there is a lien on the property resulting from a judgment, and your bankruptcy attorney was unable or did not attempt to avoid the lien, then the house can be sold but it is subject to the mortgage and judgment lien (must be paid in order to close the sale). I urge you to consult with an experienced bankruptcy attorney to discuss all details of the issues and all of your options.

Your bankruptcy discharged your personal liability on the debt but not the lien that had attached to your property. You will need to re-open your case and file a motion to avoid your lien, The rules to do this are very tricky. You will definitely need an experienced bankruptcy lawyer to help you.

Perhaps. More facts are needed to give you useful advice. If I make a few assumptions, it sounds like a creditor sued you before your BK, got a judgment and recorded a lien against your real estate. Your BK lawyer should have taken care of this during the time your case was opened. If you didn't use a lawyer in your BK, this is what happens to debtors who don't have the benefit of good representation. If you thought you could do this yourself and save money, it will now be time to pay an attorney to take care of this. If you still intend on doing this yourself, it is a very unwise decision. Here are the steps necessary to fix this:

1. File a proper motion to reopen your case;
2. If your motion to reopen is granted, prepare a proper order for the judge to sign;
3. File a motion to avoid the judgment lien(s), assuming you don't have any surplus equity beyond what you exempted;
4. Serve the motion on all necessary parties; (special rules for service must be following including using certified mail to an officer of the creditor company;
5. If no opposition is received, file a declaration of no opposition with the court;
6. If your motion is granted, prepare a proper order for the judge's signature;
7. Get a certified copy of the order from the clerk in the BK court;
8. Record the certified copy of the order in the county where the original judgment lien was recorded.

Without any mistakes/opposition, this process usually takes about 60 days. If you make mistakes, the process will take a lot longer. Don't expect the judge to "cut you any slack" for mistakes. The judge will not act as your attorney and will hold you to the same standards as a BK lawyer. The BK judges don't like the extra time they must spend reading poorly drawn motions, detecting insufficient evidence, rejecting your paperwork for deficiencies, etc. This leads to the very likely outcome of dismissing your proceedings because the judge has too many other matters to resolve and won't take a lot of time fiddling around with pro se parties.
